entry.title: üöÄ Kickstart Your SAP Career - Webinar by Armenian Code Academy
entry.content:
When: December 25 | 18:00
Format: Online
Language: Armenian (Q&A in English)
Speaker: Tsovinar Chugaszyan ‚Äì SAP Champion & Campus Ambassador

What you will learn

  • What SAP is and why Fortune 500 companies rely on it
  • SAP role pathways in Business, Technology, and Consulting
  • How to enter SAP without prior experience
  • Information about ACA‚Äôs SAP Fundamentals Program starting February 1, which is designed to give aspiring professionals a strong, job-ready introduction to the global SAP ecosystem featuring international SAP experts. The core of the offering is a 10-week intensive knowledge transfer module that provides the foundational skills required to understand and work with SAP technologies. Focus areas will be:  SAP Business Technology Platform, Cloud ERP  essentials,  Project delivery and enterprise architecture fundamentals, Security, data, DevOps and AI basics within SAP landscapes.

Special guest

Narine Kharazyan, Business Development Lead at AKNA Tech
She will share insights on opportunities for SAP-skilled professionals to work remotely with major international organizations such as SAP, Daimler, Lufthansa, and others.

Bonus for participants

Participants may receive a promo code for ACA‚Äôs upcoming SAP training program.

Registration

https://forms.gle/c48mRNwaqBAnwH318
The meeting link will be sent to registered participants.

entry.title: Resolve Overprotection
entry.content:
Resolve Overprotection

Customers easily understand the benefits of supply protection. Protecting quantities for specific customers, regions, or any defined group is a common use case in shortage situations (to learn more about supply protection check the blog titled Supply Protection in a Nutshell). 

However, protecting too much can run into the issue known as overprotection. 

S/4HANA 2025 offers a solution to identify and mitigate overprotection. 

What is Overprotection?

Every requirement, such as a sales order, must adhere to the restrictions defined by supply protection. If there is stock available but not every request receive confirmation due to supply protection, this situation is referred to as overprotection. 

The following illustration helps to understand the definition of overprotection. 


Illustration 1: Overprotection

On the left side of the illustration, a blue bar shows the available stock or supply. Colored boxes indicate the defined remaining protection for France (purple), Italy (green) and Germany (orange). Grey boxes represent the restrictions from the perspective of the related supply protection objects. In this example, the horizontal red line represents the available stock. For a demand matching the supply protection object for Germany, the grey boxes for Italy (3000) and France (4500) are to be considered as restrictions. Therefore, even a demand matching the priority 1 protection group for Germany doesn‚Äôt receive confirmation. All other potential demands also exceed the red line. This means, in all cases, the restrictions surpass availability. 

Other critical Situations


Illustration 2: Blocked SUP Objects

Assuming the stock is slightly higher, there won‚Äôt be overprotection. Demands that match the priority 1 protection for SUP Germany could receive confirmation. However, even this situation might still be considered as critical because complete markets, such as France and Italy, are blocked. In some cases, it might be acceptable that complete supply protection objects are blocked, but, in other situations, this is likely unintended and treated as a critical problem. 

If there is more supply (illustration 3), supply protection works as intended ‚Äì some demands are blocked, and only high-prioritized demands receive confirmation. Depending on the situation, this can also be seen as critical, especially if the planned protection is defined with the setting Restriction outside planned Protection. It‚Äôs obvious that other demands (not matching a protection) won‚Äôt receive confirmation. 


Illustration 3: Blocked SUP Groups

Identify Overprotection and other critical Situations

Overprotection was considered as issue because it was difficult to identify. It doesn‚Äôt appear in any app that shows availability. Within a sales order, users can see that supply protection prevents order confirmation. However, they can‚Äôt see that all other orders for the same material-plant-combination are also blocked. 

Overprotection can occur at the Restricted Product level. A restricted product is the combination of a plant-material and the defined planning level, such as plant/storage location, plant/segment, or plant/batch, for which supply protection is defined and active. 

Since supply protection is only a virtual restriction, depending on the context, the system didn‚Äôt indicate critical situations involving blocked supply protection objects.  

This has changed with the new Resolve Overprotection app which displays overprotection and other critical situations. Additionally, users can use Situation Management to receive alerts.  

Alerting for Overprotection

Customers can use the situation template CA_ATP_SUP_OVERPROTECTION to customize alerts based on their needs. Users can choose whether to receive alerts for overprotection situations or for other critical situations. Situation Management offers various settings for alert recipients, technology, and relevant criteria. 

App Resolve Overprotection

The Resolve Overprotection app provides users with a quick overview of the restricted products. By default, it sorts these restricted products on the criticality of the check result status. 


Illustration 4: The "Resolve Overprotection" App


Illustration 5: ‚ÄúResolve Overprotection‚Äù Result List

Users can view the planning level of the restricted product, the check result status, and the number of blocked supply protection objects and blocked supply protection groups.  

They can also navigate to the details of a restricted product. Here, users can see if and how much available quantity is accessible for each related protection group.


Illustration 6: Restricted Product Details View

Mitigate Overprotection

Starting from the overprotection details, users can navigate to the individual supply protection objects. They can adjust the protected quantities to improve the situation. Returning to the details page of the restricted product displays the updated check result status after retrieving the updated data using the Refresh button. 

As an alternative, you can also switch to edit mode by clicking the Edit button to simulate different mitigation options. Three different options are displayed: 

  • Prioritized reduction 
    The planned protection of all time buckets is reduced by a certain percentage. Protection groups with high priority get a low percentage reduction, while protection groups with low priority will get a high percentage reduction. 
  • Zero protection for the lowest priority 
    Only the protected quantities of the protection group with the lowest priority for each supply protection object are reduced. The reduction is 100%, completely removing the restriction by this group. 
  • Reduced Restriction Quantity by Percentage 
    The protected quantity of all related time buckets is reduced by the same percentage. 

Users can simulate the different options and decide whether to save the changes or choose another mitigation strategy. The app provides information if there is a positive available quantity accessible for the individual protection groups. There isn‚Äôt a clear recommendation for the best mitigation strategy. Users can apply the same or a different mitigation strategy after the initial one. 


Illustration 7: Mitigate Overprotection

‚ÄúOverprotection‚Äù not Addressed by the App

The Resolve Overprotection app identifies situations where supply protection restrictions exceed the available stock or supply. However, some lock issues won‚Äôt be identified as overprotection. 

For example: Suppose there is protection for one or more groups that could use the protection because there is unrestricted stock. However, matching demands are blocked by other restrictions, such as a credit block or a fully consumed product allocation (PAL) bucket. In this case, these blocked groups can‚Äôt use the defined protection, and other demands from other groups are also blocked by this non-consumable restriction. This issue arises from the setup of protection combined with the setup of product allocation.   

Summary

With the Resolve Overprotection app, along with its alerting feature, makes it easy to identify issues like overprotection and other critical situations. You can also easily mitigate the issues and overcome mutual blocking caused by supply protection. 

Nevertheless, it is crucial to set up supply protection correctly and protect only minimum quantities. There are best practices available to avoid overprotection already at an early stage. 

The setup of Supply Protection (SUP) together with Product Allocation (PAL) should be done with care. It‚Äôs recommended to use similar characteristics when defining groups in SUP and PAL. In PAL, you typically define a maximum quantity while supply protection represents minimum quantities. The interplay of both methods works best when there‚Äôs a corridor between these quantities.  

Video: Resolve Overprotection

 

Links

  • SAP Help: Resolve Overprotection 
  • SAP Help: Overprotection Alert in Supply Protection 
  • SAP Help: Avoiding and Resolving Overprotection 
  • SAP Community: Increasing Reliability with Supply Protection
  • SAP Community: Restriction by Own Protection in Supply Protection
  • SAP Community: Release Highlights of advanced Available-To-Promise (aATP) in SAP Cloud ERP, Private Edition 2025

entry.title: MCP Server for SAP ECC & S/4HANA: Unlimited ABAP Add-On for Display, Create and Update Tools
entry.content:
Introduction

It‚Äôs time to simplify integration processes between Agentic SDKs and SAP ECC & S/4HANA systems. We‚Äôd like to introduce an ABAP add-on that brings an MCP Server directly into your SAP ERP system and supports SAP ABAP releases down to 7.01.

Sounds attractive? Then let‚Äôs take a look at the architecture.

Architecture

The architecture is simple. We kept in mind that you may want to avoid middleware (such as SAP BTP applications or similar solutions) while retaining full control over:

  • Tool descriptions
    These are essential for AI orchestration‚Äìfriendly tool definitions. Standard SAP descriptions of services, tables, or other ABAP objects are not sufficient to build scalable Business AI solutions.

  • Data provisioning
    We provide a simple mechanism that allows you to nominate Tables, Views, and CDS Views to provision data to an Agentic SDK.

  • Create / Update / Delete tool onboarding
    We offer an easy mechanism to develop ABAP classes for create, update, and delete actions. Each tool requires only one method for the action and one method for metadata description.

This is how you can integrate it into any Agentic SDK:

Pic. 1. MCP Server at the SAP backend system level

What Does ‚ÄúUnlimited Display Tools‚Äù Mean?

There is an ABAP view where you can onboard Tables, Views, and CDS Views for data provisioning. Each object is automatically converted into a tool by the MCP Server.

 Pic. 2. Nomination of Tables, Views, and CDS Views for data provisioning via MCP Server

How Do You Develop Tools for Create / Update / Delete Actions?

We provide an ABAP interface that helps you create an ABAP class for each tool.

 Pic. 3. MCP Server tool creation for Create / Update / Delete actions

Really Any Agentic SDK?

Yes, absolutely. Here is an example of MCP Server consumption in ChatGPT.

The MCP Server can be connected either directly via an SICF node or through the SAP Cloud Connector.

 Pic. 4. MCP Server SICF node

In ChatGPT, you can connect the SAP MCP Server in developer mode:

 Pic. 5. Connecting MCP Server in ChatGPT

Once connected, you have direct access to SAP backend data from ChatGPT:

 Pic. 6. Leave request creation from ChatGPT via Skybuffer AI MCP Server

 Pic. 7. Purchase order data display from ChatGPT via Skybuffer AI MCP Server

Can Skybuffer AI MCP Server Work with SAP Joule?

Yes, absolutely. You can connect the MCP Server directly to an SAP Joule tool in SAP Joule Studio.

Conclusion

You now have a powerful, scalable MCP Server operating directly at the ABAP layer. You can provide high-quality tool descriptions, fully control display tool provisioning, and easily onboard create, update, and delete tools without the need to build OData services on top of them.

The solution works with any Agentic SDK and is ready for enterprise deployment as an ABAP add-on.

entry.title: Re: Introducing the Gantt Chart Custom Widget for SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
You are using an SAC model with a live connection to your SAP BW query correct?
Your SAC model will have two entries for each column/field from your SAP BW query:
The technical ID, e.g. "My_StartDate_123abc" and the corresponding description, e.g. "My Start Date".

Yes, I believe you must use a DateTimestamp, not just date.
Get your SAP BW Query Designer person to include those fields/columns  (dateTimestamps) in the query.

You also must address this issue:
  Does "Phase" column really contain the parent ID?
  E.g. ID column reads "1", but Phase column reads "03".
  Is there an ID in your table with "03"?

I kindly suggest you really go thru this thread, starting at the very top and work your way thru it.

entry.title: SAP-RPT-1: A Step-by-Step Guide on Getting Started
entry.content:
SAP-RPT-1 is now generally available, so let‚Äôs put it to some good work! Building on our previous blog post, this step-by-step walkthrough will take you from zero to your first successful inference. Let‚Äôs get started!

Prerequisites

To get access to the model variants, you will first need to have a working AI Core instance under the extended plan (see SAP Note on region availability). We generally recommend the use of AI Launchpad alongside your AI Core instance and you can follow the here to get started with SAP generative AI hub.

Deploy SAP-RPT-1

Note: This guide only covers the UI flow on SAP AI Launchpad. You can also deploy the model via the existing AI APIs from AI Core. Refer to the help guide for more details.

Using AI Launchpad, you will find the 2 model variants of SAP-RPT-1 in the Model Library within generative AI hub.

Model Library on SAP generative AI hub showing the new model versions of SAP-RPT-1

Select your desired model variant and you should see a Deploy button on the model page. Click Deploy to start a model deployment (See ‚ë†). Once the deployment is created, you will see that the count increases by 1 (See ‚ë°).

Deploying SAP-RPT-1

Deploying the model will take a few minutes. You can monitor the progress via the Deployments tab.

Deployment of SAP-RPT-1

Deployments on SAP generative AI hub

First Predictions with SAP-RPT-1

Once the model has been deployed, you should see that a deployment URL is now available.

Deployment URL for SAP-RPT-1

To make predictions, you will need to post requests to the provided deployment URL. The table below summarises the key details:

URL<deployment url>/predict
MethodPOST
HeadersRefer to the help guide for the header requirements
Request PayloadSee the next section

Request Payload

Given an example where you would like to the price and the cost center of products. You can mark the fields that you want to predict with a configurable placeholder value, for instance, [PREDICT]. Here is how the request payload looks like when using the /predict endpoint for the given example. 

{
    "prediction_config": {
        "target_columns": [
            {
                "name": "COSTCENTER",
                "prediction_placeholder": "[PREDICT]",
                "task_type": "classification"
            },
            {
                "name": "PRICE",
                "prediction_placeholder": "[PREDICT]",
                "task_type": "regression"
            }
        ]
    },
    "index_column": "ID",
    "rows": [
        {
            "PRODUCT": "Couch",
            "PRICE": "[PREDICT]",
            "ORDERDATE": "28-11-2025",
            "ID": "35",
            "COSTCENTER": "[PREDICT]"
        },
        {
            "PRODUCT": "Office Chair",
            "PRICE": 150.8,
            "ORDERDATE": "02-11-2025",
            "ID": "44",
            "COSTCENTER": "Office Furniture"
        },
        {
            "PRODUCT": "Server Rack",
            "PRICE": 210.0,
            "ORDERDATE": "01-11-2025",
            "ID": "108",
            "COSTCENTER": "Data Infrastructure"
        }, 
        {
            "PRODUCT": "Server Rack",
            "PRICE": "[PREDICT]",
            "ORDERDATE": "01-11-2025",
            "ID": "104",
            "COSTCENTER": "[PREDICT]"
        },
        ...
    ],
    "data_schema": {
        "PRODUCT": {
            "dtype": "string"
        },
        "PRICE": {
            "dtype": "numeric"
        },
        "ORDERDATE": {
            "dtype": "date"
        },
        "ID": {
            "dtype": "string"
        },
        "COSTCENTER": {
            "dtype": "string"
        }
    }
}

You can refer to the help guide for all available parameters in the request payload. You can also provide the context rows in row-wise format (as seen in the example above) or in column-wise format. 

We would recommend that you specify the data_schema of your context data wherever possible, so that the value in each column is parsed correctly. In the case where the schema is not provided, the model will attempt to infer the data types of the columns. Do note that the model can only accept YYYY-MM-DD and YYYYMMDD for the date type.

Response Payload

Upon sending this request to SAP-RPT-1, the model will return the predictions for the marked fields. Here is how the response payload looks like when using the /predict endpoint for the given example.

{
  "id": "a45971e6-a0c7-447b-a641-b0a4dea54a91",
  "status": {
    "code": 0,
    "message": "ok"
  },
  "predictions": [
    {
      "COSTCENTER": [
        {
          "prediction": "Office Furniture",
          "confidence": 0.97
        }
      ],
      "PRICE": [
        {
          "prediction": 162.54498291015625,
          "confidence": null
        }
      ],
      "ID": "35"
    },
    {
      "COSTCENTER": [
        {
          "prediction": "Data Infrastructure",
          "confidence": 0.88
        }
      ],
      "PRICE": [
        {
          "prediction": 209.23606872558594,
          "confidence": null
        }
      ],
      "ID": "104"
    }
  ],
  "metadata": {
    "num_columns": 5,
    "num_rows": 2,
    "num_predictions": 4,
    "num_query_rows": 2
  }
}

You can refer to the help guide for all available parameters in the response payload.

Using SAP-RPT-1 in your Use Cases

SAP-RPT-1 comes in two variants, SAP-RPT-1-small and SAP-RPT-1-large (refer to this help guide for more detailed specs). SAP recommends using the -small variant for medium-complexity problems, where low inference latency is crucial. Our internal testing shows that for many real-world use cases, SAP-RPT-1-small yields predictions in less than a second2. Depending on the number of columns as well as the intrinsic complexity of the use case, we found that a context of 500 ‚Äì 2000 rows can be sufficient in many cases to yield best-in-class prediction quality.

For very complex use cases and with a large number of columns influencing predictions, larger context window sizes can be required to achieve highest quality predictions. For these cases, we recommend SAP-RPT-1-large, which accepts up to 64000 (65536) context rows and up to 256 columns. This model is built to achieve highest accuracy predictions for complex enterprise use cases. Runtime of this model is typically somewhat longer than for SAP-RPT-1-small ‚Äì our own internal tests show that many use cases complete within 2 ‚Äì 8 seconds [1]. For a balanced trade-off between prediction quality, latency and costs, starting with 4000 ‚Äì 8000 context rows were found by our engineers to work well for many use cases.

[1] Please note that these runtimes are merely an indication based on SAP‚Äôs own tests. Actual runtimes may vary depending on the exact use case and chosen modeling, so customers are advised to perform their own testing in a production-like setting.

Finding the Right Context

Users who are familiar with narrow AI models regularly ask what they should do if they have a tabular prediction problem where many 100,000s or millions of rows of labelled data are available.

As narrow AI models perform a training step, where they look at context data typically sequentially, they can easily consider millions of rows one-by-one ‚Äì it just makes model training take longer. While on the other hand, foundation models like SAP-RPT-1 have a limited context window size. So, isn‚Äôt this a severe limitation of foundation models ‚Äì particularly in enterprise settings where large volumes of data are common?

It turns out that it‚Äôs not, at least not in practice. Due to its efficient design and large-scale pre-training, we found that with only 1000 or 2000 rows, SAP-RPT-1 can outperform traditional narrow AI models that have been trained on millions of rows for the same use case. Here, we invite you to learn more about relational pre-trained transformers, their stunning performance and other benefits in our tech blog post on SAP-RPT-1.

So now the question becomes: how do you pick the right context rows (say, 2000 for the -small variant) for your use case? The answer is simple and somewhat surprising: most often, it doesn‚Äôt matter much in practice. If there are 200,000 rows of labelled training data and you simply pick 2000 rows at random, our experiments indicate that this is sufficient to achieve best-in-class performance for most enterprise use cases.

Understandably, there are edge cases where we would recommend slightly more diligent approaches to select the right context data. Such cases include classification use cases with a high number of target classes and use cases that show strong data drift. Some suggested approaches would be to apply stratified sampling to ensure all target classes are represented, and sampling with a bias for recency.

With that said, we are working on providing tooling to make context selection even simpler and integrated into your data landscape, so stay tuned! But for now, we recommend you start simple and see for yourself how in-context learning with a limited number of rows can boost performance of your tabular enterprise AI use cases.

Ready to Try SAP-RPT-1?

To jumpstart your journey, we have prepared a comprehensive with sample requests that you can use right away. Simply download the collection from our repository and customise it with your context data.

What‚Äôs Next

We are continuously working to improve your developer experience. for AI, allowing your developers to seamlessly integrate the model into their applications with just a few lines of code. Stay tuned for more updates!

We are excited to see what you will build with SAP-RPT-1. Get started today, and do not hesitate to share your feedback and use cases with us. Your insights can help shape the future of our AI offerings.

Happy building! üöÄ

entry.title: Reduce Migration Data Validation Time to 30 Seconds: Automate SAP HANA Table Row Counts
entry.content:
During any SAP migration project such as backup/restore, tenant copy or any lift-and-shift migration activities- validating migrated content is critical. Ensuring data completeness and accuracy requires comparing row counts for business-critical tables between the source and target SAP systems.

As a part of the migration process:

  • Row counts are captured on the source system just after application ramp-down and before shutting down the database.
  • Row counts are captured on the target system immediately after migration.

Traditional Approach

Each table requires manual SQL execution on both systems.

This process is time-consuming and effort-intensive, often taking 30 - 40 minutes per system, increasing potential business downtime.

Automated Approach

To streamline validation, an automated Bash script was developed to perform end-to-end row-count extraction and validation.

  • Execution time: Under 30 seconds for both the systems.
  • Downtime savings: Approximately 1.5 hours avoided.
  • Efficiency improvement: Significant reduction in manual effort and risk of errors.

Script Overview

#!/bin/bash

################################################################################
# Important Instructions
# 
# - This script can be executed on any application server using the sidadm user.
# - Update the table names or WHERE clause entries as needed for your specific landscape.
# - Modify the path of the output file when running it on the source system to ensure proper access.
# - Ensure that the output of any additional queries returns a single-row value, as this script is designed to operate in that manner.
#
# Usage Instructions:
# ‚Ä¢ On the source system: Execute this script after ramp-down starts and once the application is stopped.
# ‚Ä¢ In the HEC environment: Run the script immediately after the database restore and before starting SWPM.
# ‚Ä¢ Ensure hdbuserstore is correctly configured before executing the script after migration, 
#   as it uses the default key as a reference.
################################################################################

# --- Configuration ---
OUTPUT_FILE="/install/table_row_counts.csv"   # Change path and extension as needed, e.g., .xls
TABLES=(
    MARA MARC LFA1 KNA1 TRDIR EKKO LIKP MSEG MCH1 MARD MBEW EKPO EKES VBAP MVKE CHVW
    VBAK LIPS BSIS BSIK BSID ANEP BKPF EDID4 RF05L USR04 USR10 UST04 AGR_USERS AGR_1251
    AGR_1250 AGR_AGRS USR02 TDDAT T000 TBTC_JOB_DATA E070 SEC_POLICY_CUST PAHI TPALOG
)

# --- Get Start Time ---
# Default timezone is EDT; change to 'Asia/Kolkata' for IST or 'America/Chicago' for CST
START_TIME=$(hdbsql -U DEFAULT -Axj "SELECT UTCTOLOCAL(CURRENT_TIMESTAMP, 'America/New_York', 'platform') FROM DUMMY;" | tail -1)
echo "Start Time (EDT): $START_TIME" > "$OUTPUT_FILE"
echo "Table|RowCount" >> "$OUTPUT_FILE"

# --- Loop through tables to get row counts ---
for table in "${TABLES[@]}"; do
    row_count=$(hdbsql -U DEFAULT -Axj "SELECT COUNT(*) FROM $table" | tail -1 | tr -d -c 0-9)
    echo "$table - $row_count"
    echo "${table}|${row_count}" >> "$OUTPUT_FILE"
done

# --- Additional Queries ---
echo "" >> "$OUTPUT_FILE"
echo "Filtered Row Results (Full Values):" >> "$OUTPUT_FILE"

ADDITIONAL_QUERIES=(
    "SELECT * FROM USR04 WHERE BNAME='DDIC'"
    "SELECT * FROM LIKP WHERE VBELN='00839' AND ERDAT='20250612'"
    "SELECT COUNT(*) FROM M_TABLES WHERE SCHEMA_NAME='SAPS4'"
    "SELECT UTCTOLOCAL(CURRENT_TIMESTAMP, 'America/New_York', 'platform') FROM DUMMY;"
)

for query in "${ADDITIONAL_QUERIES[@]}"; do
    row_value=$(hdbsql -U DEFAULT -Axj "$query" | tail -1)
    echo "$query - $row_value"
    echo "$query - $row_value" >> "$OUTPUT_FILE"
done

Script Analysis:

1. Shebang Line

#!/bin/bash

  • Indicates the script should run using Bash.

2. Output File

OUTPUT_FILE="/install/table_row_counts.csv"
  • Defines where results are saved.
  • To change location or format:
OUTPUT_FILE="/home/user/output/table_row_counts.xls"

Note: Bash outputs plain text; excel can open .csv as a spreadsheet.

3. Tables Array

TABLES=(MARA MARC LFA1 ...)
  • Contains SAP HANA table names for row-count validation.
  • Add new tables by appending to this array.

4. Timestamp Capture

START_TIME=$(hdbsql -U DEFAULT -Axj "SELECT UTCTOLOCAL(CURRENT_TIMESTAMP, 'America/New_York', 'platform') FROM DUMMY;" | tail -1)

  • Converts UTC to EDT.
  • Options:
    • -A: no headers
    • -x: simplified output
    • -j: JSON output
  • To change timezone:
    • SELECT UTCTOLOCAL(CURRENT_TIMESTAMP, 'Asia/Kolkata', 'platform') FROM DUMMY;

5. Row Count Loop

for table in "${TABLES[@]}"; do row_count=$(hdbsql ... ) echo "${table}|${row_count}" >> "$OUTPUT_FILE" done
  • Iterates over each table.
  • tr -d -c 0-9 ensures only numeric row counts are captured.
  • Prints to terminal and writes to CSV.

6. Additional Queries

ADDITIONAL_QUERIES=( "SELECT ..." )
  • Can include filtered queries or custom checks which only contains a single-row result.
  • Iterates over each query and appends results to the output file.
  • Add new queries by expanding this array.

Summary / Quick Tips

Task How to Customize

Change file location or formatModify OUTPUT_FILE path; use .csv for simplicity
Change timezoneUpdate UTCTOLOCAL function parameter (America/Chicago, Asia/Kolkata)
Add more tablesAppend to the first TABLES array
Add more queries

Append SQL statements to ADDITIONAL_QUERIES array

All additional queries must return a single-row result; failing to do so will prevent the script from producing the intended output.

 

‚úîÔ∏è Outcome:

This script dramatically reduces SAP migration validation time while ensuring data integrity, supporting faster and safer migrations.

Here is a clear step-by-step procedure to create, configure, and execute your .sh script in a Linux directory:

Step 1: Open a Terminal

Log in to the Linux server where you want to run the SAP HANA row-count script.

Step 2: Navigate to the Directory

Decide where you want to store the script, for example /migration. Then navigate to it:

cd /migration
If the directory doesn‚Äôt exist, create it:

mkdir -p /migration cd /migration


Step 3: Create a New .sh File

Use a text editor like vi, nano, or vim to create a new file. For example:

vi hana_row_count.sh
This opens the editor for a new file named hana_row_count.sh.

Step 4: Paste the Script

In the editor, press i (for vi) to enter insert mode.

Paste the entire script content (your SAP HANA row-count Bash script).

Example:

#!/bin/bash # Your full script content goes here

Save and exit:

In vi, press Esc, then type :wq! and press Enter

Step 5: Assign Execute Permissions

Make the script executable using chmod:

chmod +x hana_row_count.sh

+x gives execution permission.

You can verify permissions using:

ls -l hana_row_count.sh

You should see something like:

-rwxr-xr-x 1 user user 2048 Dec 17 12:00 hana_row_count.sh

Step 6: Execute the Script

Run the script from the terminal:

./hana_row_count.sh

Or, if it requires sidadm or a specific user, switch to that user first:

su - sidadm ./hana_row_count.sh

Step 7: Verify Output

The script will generate an output file at the path you defined, for example:

/migration/table_row_counts.csv

Check the content:

cat /migration/table_row_counts.csv

 


‚úîÔ∏èQuick Tips:

  • Always check the script path in OUTPUT_FILE before executing.
  • If running on SAP HANA after migration, ensure hdbuserstore is properly configured.
  • Use full paths for output and utilities in the script to avoid path-related errors.
  • Test the script on a small table first to confirm it works before running on all tables.

entry.title: SAP Digital Manufacturing 2511: Platform Improvements at a Glance
entry.content:
Release 2511 of SAP Digital Manufacturing further strengthens the platform with a set of targeted enhancements designed to elevate stability, performance, and operational excellence across key manufacturing areas. This release builds on existing capabilities to enable more reliable, scalable, and efficient day-to-day operations in productive environments.

Many of these enhancements are directly informed by customer feedback and real-world usage, contributing to smoother operations and an even more consistent and predictable system experience at scale.

The following sections highlight the key enhancements delivered with release 2511 and the tangible value they bring to manufacturing operations.

 

 Automation

Introducing the MQTT Agent Management in Manage Message Broker app

Starting from release 2511, customers can now use the MQTT Agent Management in the Managed Message Broker app, simplifying how customers operate and troubleshoot MQTT-based integrations. Automation engineers can now centrally manage MQTT agents directly from the cloud, without needing to access the local Control Center. This includes starting and stopping agents, adjusting log levels, and viewing detailed logs for specific time periods. The enhanced UI also provides immediate visibility into deployment status, certificate issues, and connection errors, enabling faster root-cause analysis. From a business perspective, this enhancement reduces operational overhead, minimizes downtime caused by misconfigurations, and empowers teams with cloud-based transparency and control over messaging infrastructures, ultimately improving reliability and lowering total cost of ownership.

Consult our Help Page, to learn more about the Manage Message Broker app.

Enhanced SOAP Service import functionality

This release also introduces an improvement in the Service Registry app by enhancing SOAP service import functionality. Production engineers can now import multiple SOAP services from SAP ERP into the same group path without the risk of overwriting existing service schemas. Each imported service is automatically assigned a unique name and ID under the same group path, ensuring seamless organization and preventing conflicts. Additionally, users can edit general details and the web server of the imported SOAP service, although manual schema edits remain restricted. If schema changes are required, engineers can simply re-import a service with the same ID, which will overwrite the previous version.

This enhancement reduces integration complexity and accelerates system connectivity, enabling faster onboarding of services without downtime or manual intervention. By minimizing the risk of schema conflicts, businesses can maintain operational continuity and improve agility in adapting to changing production requirements.

 Click here to learn more about SOAP Service import functionality.

New reserved words for Production Process Designer input validation

To strengthen security and ensure robust validation in production processes, new reserved words to the Production Process Designer (PPD) were added. These reserved words trigger validation checks whenever they appear in critical areas such as input/output parameter names, script code content, condition expressions, and message content. By enforcing these checks, the system prevents the use of sensitive or potentially harmful keywords that could lead to security vulnerabilities. The newly introduced reserved words include variables like execution, task, await, and context, as well as functions such as clientTokenLoader, cloudConnectorUtil, and processInstanceNamingService.
This feature enhances process security and compliance, reducing the risk of unauthorized access or system breaches. By ensuring that production processes adhere to strict validation rules, businesses can safeguard intellectual property, maintain regulatory compliance, and build trust in automated manufacturing workflows.

Learn more about Production Process Designer on SAP Help portal.

New toggle for archiving process

Moreover, this release introduces a data archiving feature: the ability to enable or disable archiving processes through a simple toggle. The trigger for this toggle is the fact that, customers face a strict four-week retention period for process instance logs, after which data was permanently deleted. With this new toggle, users gain full control over data conservation, allowing them to archive logs indefinitely based on business needs. By default, archiving is disabled, but once activated, the system includes logs from the previous day and continues archiving until the toggle is turned off. This flexibility ensures that organizations can preserve critical historical data for compliance, audits, or long-term analysis without worrying about automatic deletion, while still maintaining efficient storage management.

Consult our SAP Help Portal to learn the details about managing archived logs.

Edge

Filter edge transactions based on business objects like SFC, order, etc. in the Monitor Edge Transactions app

In release 2511, SAP Digital Manufacturing enhances the Monitor Edge Transactions app with new filtering options that make it much easier for users to trace and analyze transactions sent from Edge to the cloud. Previously, filtering was limited to timestamps and transaction status, forcing users to manually sift through large volumes of data. The new enhancement allows users to filter transactions by key business objects, such as SFC, order, BOM, and operation activity, giving immediate visibility into all transactions associated with a specific manufacturing context. From a business perspective, this enhancement improves troubleshooting speed, auditability, and transparency across hybrid Edge‚Äìcloud deployments. Customers can now pinpoint issues faster, validate data flows more efficiently, ultimately reducing downtime and operational effort.

Consult our SAP Help Portal, if needed.

Execution

Inventory API (V2)

Additionally, a redesigned and more robust set of Inventory API V2 and Batch API V2 endpoints was introduced, bringing clearer structures and stricter validations. The new Inventory API V2 consolidates previously separate endpoints, reduces redundancy, and provides more powerful querying as well as improved bulk-creation capabilities, all with enforced data-type, required-field, and duplication checks to prevent inconsistent or corrupted inventory records. Field names have been clarified to better reflect their purpose. In addition, the new Batch API V2 offers dedicated endpoints to create batches, retrieve batch data, and update batch characteristics with greater reliability. From a business perspective, these enhancements improve data quality, stability, and integration reliability across inventory and batch processes. Customers benefit from cleaner APIs, fewer downstream errors, easier debugging, and more predictable behaviour in automated production workflows, driving stronger end-to-end process integrity.

Refer our SAP Help Portal to learn further details about inventory.

 

Auto assembly isolation and performance improvement

A performance upgrade is now available for Auto-Assembly as a result of optimization, redefinition of the infrastructure to improve performance and robustness. The changes help to reduce latency on the shop floor, improves system stability under load, and ensure smoother processing of large, complex assemblies. The result is faster execution, higher throughput, and a more reliable user experience for operators and production teams.

 

New Work Instruction API for attachment creation

In the Execution area, this release delivers some performance improvements across key data-intensive APIs, specifically the 3-Routing API and the Work Instruction Attachment API. Previously, routing structures with hundreds of components could take up to 10‚Äì11 seconds to process. By introducing intelligent caching mechanisms, the same scenarios now execute in around 100 milliseconds, offering a boost in responsiveness.

Consult our SAP Help Portal to learn the details about work instruction & work instruction attached file.

 

Retrieve Routing API enhancement with cache

Similarly, adding attachment points to Work Instructions, often involving more than 1,000 existing entries, has been optimized through a new dedicated public API that adds entries incrementally rather than regenerating the full list. This leads to faster execution on the shop floor, more reliable automation, and better overall system performance at scale.

 

Unit of Measure (UoM) short and long text display in Data Collection plugin

Additionally, this release introduces a small but highly practical enhancement to Data Collection: Operators can now see both the unit of measure code and its descriptive text when entering parameter values. Previously, the UI displayed only the UoM code, which worked well for common units like kg or l but often led to confusion when customers used less familiar or industry-specific units. The updated experience now shows the short text directly on the board and allows users to view the full descriptive text when needed. This improvement reduces operator errors, accelerates data entry, and strengthens data quality, especially in environments where accurate measurement is critical. It‚Äôs a lightweight enhancement driven by customer feedback that meaningfully improves usability on the shop floor.

 

Resource Orchestration

Schedule and reschedule public API with infinite mode support

Public scheduling APIs now support multiple scheduling modes, enabling both infinite scheduling and find-slot scheduling via API calls. This allows external systems and custom integrations to control how operations are scheduled, either by inserting them into the next available slot or scheduling them even if it creates overloaded blocks. These enhancements strengthen end-to-end order consistency, reduce manual correction effort, and give customers greater control over automated scheduling scenarios, leading to more reliable planning, fewer production delays, and smoother ERP-to-DM synchronization.

Order quantity reduction

Speaking of Resource orchestration area, there are two newly introduced enhancements that improve planning accuracy and scheduling flexibility. First, the new Quantity Reduction capability allows supervisors to seamlessly adjust order quantities in SAP DM when quantities are reduced in ERP. Once an order is released, DM now detects mismatches and provides an intuitive interface where supervisors can decide from which operation splits the reduced quantity should be deducted, ensuring that planned quantities, splits, and operations stay fully aligned without manual reconciliation.

Summary

With release 2511, SAP Digital Manufacturing continues to enhance the quality, performance, and operability of the platform in areas that matter most to daily production. The improvements delivered in this release simplify operations, improve responsiveness on the shop floor, and increase transparency across manufacturing processes. Together, they help you, our customers, run their manufacturing landscapes more efficiently today while building a strong foundation for future enhancements.

More resources

SAP Digital Manufacturing | SAP Community

SAP Digital Manufacturing | SAP Help Portal

SAP Roadmap Explorer for SAP Digital Manufacturing

SAP Digital Manufacturing on SAP Supply Chain Management Engagement Hub

entry.title: Move Requirements between Projects
entry.content:
Move requirements between projects 

In real projects, things do not always go as planned. Sometimes requirements are created in the wrong project. Sometimes the project scope changes. Sometimes work is reorganized across teams. Until now, fixing this often meant recreating requirements manually, which took time and increased the risk of mistakes.

With this new feature, users can now move requirements from one project to another directly in SAP Cloud ALM. This saves time, reduces manual effort, and helps keep all information accurate and connected. Most importantly, it preserves traceability so nothing important is lost along the way.

When can a requirement be moved(Conditions)

To keep data consistent and processes clean, a few conditions must be met before moving a requirement.

  1. The requirement must be in In Refinement status.
  2.  No feature should be assigned to the requirement at the time of moving.

Who can move the requirements between projects 

To ensure proper control and governance, only users with the role of Project Lead or Project Administrator are allowed to perform the move action.

These rules make sure that only early stage requirements are moved. This avoids any impact on active development work and helps teams stay aligned.

Why this matters

Earlier in projects, it often happened that requirements were created across different projects during the initial phases. When the business later decided that some of these requirements actually belonged to a different project, there was no simple way to move them.

The only option was to mark the requirements as obsolete and delete them. Consultants then had to either download and upload the requirements into another project or manually create new requirements in the correct project. This process was time consuming, error prone, and often led to loss of context and traceability.

With the new move requirement feature, this problem is now addressed. Requirements can be moved directly to the correct project at an early stage. This makes the process much simpler from an individual perspective and also from a project perspective. Teams can respond faster to business decisions, avoid unnecessary rework, and keep their projects clean and well structured.

 

Business example

Imagine a customer running two implementation projects, one for Finance and one for Sales. During early requirement refinement, a requirement related to pricing logic is accidentally created in the Finance project. Later, the team realizes that this requirement actually belongs to the Sales project and has not yet been picked up for development.

With the new move requirement feature, the consultant can simply move the requirement to the correct Sales project. There is no need to recreate the requirement, re enter details, or worry about losing comments or history. The team saves time, avoids errors, and can continue refining the requirement in the right project without disruption.

We hope you enjoy this improvement and find it helpful in your daily work with SAP Cloud ALM. As always, your feedback is welcome and helps us continue to improve the product.

entry.title: How to notify Non-SuccessFactors User via mail about leave creation
entry.content:
Context:

We are using SAP SuccessFactors as the HR system for several legal entities in a consulting organization. Employees often work on global projects, and the respective project managers are not always SuccessFactors users, as not all legal entities within the group use SF as their HR system.

For each employee in SF, the project manager‚Äôs email address is available in SuccessFactors as a string field, being imported via interface from a global data source.

Business requirement:
When an employee creates a leave request (no approval required), the respective project manager should at least receive an email notification.

Constraints:

  • The project manager is not a SuccessFactors user

  • Project managers change frequently ‚Üí creating technical or dummy users is not feasible

  • SuccessFactors workflows and notifications cannot reference pure string email fields (at least based on my knowledge)

  • Approval by the project manager is not required, only an information email

Question:
Is there any standard or recommended way within SuccessFactors to trigger an email notification to a non-SF user's email address stored as a string field? Or is an external integration (e.g. Intelligent Services + middleware) the only viable approach?

Any best practices or real-life implementations would be highly appreciated.

Thanks a lot in advance!! 

SAP SuccessFactors Platform SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central

entry.title: Re: SAP Fiori tools 2601 update ‚Äì Mobile Device Preview, Building Blocks, and AI-Driven Productivity
entry.content:
@nsathya 

While our tooling does not introduce its own proprietary password-less authentication mechanism, it fully supports ABAP reentrance tickets for login. Reentrance tickets are a standard SAP mechanism that enable password-less reauthentication once a user has been authenticated by the ABAP system, and they are commonly used as part of SSO architectures in SAP landscapes. In practical terms, this means:
  • The user authenticates once against the ABAP backend using an SSO-enabled method (for example, SAP logon tickets, X.509 certificates, or other SAP-supported SSO mechanisms configured in the system).
  • Our tooling then uses the issued reentrance ticket to access the ABAP backend without prompting the user for credentials again.
  • This provides a seamless, password-less user experience within the scope of the active session, consistent with SAP-recommended SSO patterns.

entry.title: Re: Accelerating Financial Close: Integrating SAP Datasphere with SAP Group Reporting
entry.content:
Hi Brian,

You‚Äôve identified the exact bottleneck: forcing SAP S/4HANA to calculate rules during extraction is resource-intensive. The SAP Datasphere approach solves this by shifting the "heavy lifting". Instead of extracting pre-calculated results, we move the raw base data to SAP Datasphere and apply the reporting logic within its modeling layer. This offloads the runtime calculations from S/4HANA to SAP Datasphere‚Äôs high-performance engine, keeping your core system fast while delivering the governed results SAP Group Reporting needs.

Bernd

entry.title: Introducing Our Next EGI: Joule Prerequisites and Activation
entry.content:
Program Overview: 

This 3-day implementation program equips your team with the knowledge and hands-on experience needed to successfully deploy SAP‚Äôs AI-powered digital assistant, Joule. Through expert-led sessions and guided configuration exercises, participants will navigate the complex technical architecture and complete critical pre-requisites for a production ready Joule implementation. 

 

What You‚Äôll Achieve 

 

Day 1 ‚Äì Foundation and Architecture 

Gain a comprehensive understanding of Joule‚Äôs architecture and the Business Technology Platform (BTP) ecosystem. You will explore how critical components ‚Äì Cloud Identity Services (CIS), Build Work Zone (BWZ), BTP and Line-of-Business solutions ‚Äì interconnect to power Joule‚Äôs capabilities. Through live demonstrations and hands-on exercises, participants will navigate BTP account structures, understand entitlements and subscriptions, and validate system prerequisites. By the end of day one, you will have assessed your organisations readiness and begun to configure your dedicated Joule environment. 

On a BTP account we will have a live demo after integration with SuccessFactors 

 Hands On 

Translate theory into action. Guided by our experts, you will step into your own BTP environment to assess your landscape, confirm sub-accounts, validate key subscriptions and officially designate your primary Joule subaccount.  

 

Day 2 ‚Äì Integration and Activation 

Build on foundational knowledge with deep-dive sessions into identity management and user provisioning. Learn how Cloud Identity Systems integrates with your corporate Identity Provider and enables secure authentication for Joule. Configure Build Work Zone to serve as the unified interface where Joule delivers AI-powered insights across your SAP landscape. Participants will complete provisioning tasks, establish trust relationships between systems and expose content from your chosen Line-of-Business solutions. 

 Hands On 

You will execute the final configuration pieces by integrating your corporate Identity Provider with CIS, establishing system trusts, running user provisioning and exposing content from a live LOB solution into Build Work Zone. You will leave the session with a configured and functional platform ready for activation. 

 

Day 3 ‚Äì Wrap Up and Trouble Shooting 

This is your dedication implementation support session. This day is reserved for you to work directly with our SAP experts in a hands-on, collaborative session. They will help you troubleshoot any specific issues encountered during the previous two days. 

 

Program Deliverables 

  • Completed BTP environment configuration with designated Joule sub-account 
  • Configured identity management and user provisioning workflows 
  • Build Work Zone instance integrated with your SAP applications 
  • Validated prerequisites checklist ensuring deployment readiness 
  • Expert guidance on common implementation challenges and best practices 

 

Who Should Attend 

Technical Architects, Security and Identity Management Specialists, BTP administrators and Architects, and SAP BASIS professionals responsible for implementing and managing SAP‚Äôs AI and integration technologies. 

 

Investment Value 

Accelerate your Joule deployment while avoiding common pitfalls. Our expert-guided approach ensures your team develops competency in managing SAP‚Äôs AI infrastructure, maximising your return on investment.

entry.title: Create a proxy in APIM
entry.content:
Overview and prerequisites

  • Access: SAP BTP subaccount with Integration Suite (CPI) and API Management service enabled.
  • iFlow: A deployed iFlow with an HTTP endpoint (or OData) that you can call.
  • Auth: Credentials or OAuth client for the iFlow‚Äôs endpoint.
  • Portal: API Portal (to build proxies, policies, products) and Developer Portal (for application registration and subscription).



Prepare your iFlow endpoint
‚Ä¢ Locate endpoint: Open your iFlow, go to the sender adapter (e.g., HTTP), and note the runtime URL (host + path).
‚Ä¢ Test direct call: Use a tool like Postman to confirm the iFlow works with its native authentication (Basic or OAuth).
‚Ä¢ Decide security model: Choose how API callers will authenticate. A common pattern is API key at the proxy plus Basic/OAuth from proxy to target.



Create the API proxy

In API Portal

  1. Create API:
    • Name: A clear name (e.g., order-iflow-proxy).
    • Base path: What external consumers will call (e.g., /orders).
    • Target: The iFlow endpoint URL (runtime host + full path).
  2. Resources:
    • Define resource paths: For example, /create, /status/{id}, or keep root if it‚Äôs a single-operation iFlow.
    • Methods: Allow only what you need (e.g., POST for create, GET for status).
  3. Proxy settings:
  • Virtual host: Select your API domain (e.g., default).
  • TLS: Ensure HTTPS is used for both proxy and target.
  • Target auth: Configure Basic or OAuth 2.0 to call CPI from the proxy

 

Add policies
Attach policies to the proxy for authentication, protection, and headers. Below are common, production-safe choices with XML examples you can paste into API Management.

Security and access control

  • Verify API Key: Require an API key from the caller (typically via apikey header or query parameter).

<VerifyAPIKey name="verify-api-key">
<APIKey ref="request.header.apikey"/>
</VerifyAPIKey>

  • Attachment:
        Request flow (PreFlow) before routing to target.
    • Basic authentication to CPI (if applicable):

<AssignMessage name="assign-target-basic-auth">
<Set>
<Headers>
<Header name="Authorization">Basic {base64EncodedUser:Password}</Header>
</Headers>
</Set>
<AssignTo createNew="false">request</AssignTo>
</AssignMessage>

 

      • Replace with a Key-Value Map reference or encrypted variable; do not hardcode credentials in production.
    • OAuth 2.0 (client credentials) to CPI (alternative):


      <OAuthV2 name="oauth-to-cpi">
      <Operation>GetAccessToken</Operation>
      <Credentials>
      <Key>client_id_from_kvm</Key>
      <Secret>client_secret_from_kvm</Secret>
      </Credentials>
      <SupportedGrantTypes>
      <GrantType>client_credentials</GrantType>
      </SupportedGrantTypes>
      <AccessTokenLocation>request.header.Authorization</AccessTokenLocation>
      <AccessTokenPrefix>Bearer</AccessTokenPrefix>
      <GenerateResponse>false</GenerateResponse>
      <ResourceOwnerKey>token_cache_key</ResourceOwnerKey>
      <TokenURL>https://<cpi-host>/oauth/token</TokenURL>
      </OAuthV2>


    • Traffic management and protection

      • Quota: Limit total calls in a time window.
        <Quota name="quota-per-app">
        <Interval>1</Interval>
        <TimeUnit>hour</TimeUnit>
        <Allow>1000</Allow>
        <Distributed>true</Distributed>
        <Identifier ref="verify-api-key.client_id"/>
        </Quota>
      •  Attach in Request PreFlow.
        ‚Ä¢ Spike Arrest: Smooth burst traffic.
        <SpikeArrest name="spike-arrest">
        <Rate>100ps</Rate>
        </SpikeArrest>
      • JSON Threat Protection (if payload is JSON):

        <JSONThreatProtection name="json-threat-protection">
        <MaxObjectDepth>20</MaxObjectDepth>
        <MaxArraySize>10000</MaxArraySize>
        <MaxStringLength>100000</MaxStringLength>
        </JSONThreatProtection>


      • Package into a product

        Products bundle proxies with plans and quotas for controlled access via the Developer Portal.

        1. Create Product:
          • Name: e.g., Orders-API-Product.
          • APIs: Add your order-iflow-proxy.
          • Plans: Define one or more plans with quota and description (e.g., Standard: 1000 calls/hour).
      • Publish Product:
        • Visibility: Set to public or restricted.
        • Attach documentation: Short ‚ÄúGetting Started‚Äù and endpoint specs for developers.

      • Create an application and subscribe

        Applications represent consumers and issue credentials like API keys.

        1. Developer Portal:
          • Register Application: Provide a name, description, and contact.
          • Credentials: The portal generates an API key (client ID).
          • Subscribe: Choose the Orders-API-Product and the plan.
      • Distribute API key:
        • Usage: In client calls, set apikey header (or query param) matching your VerifyAPIKey policy.
        • Rotation: Maintain multiple keys for rotation and revocation.

entry.title: Re: Date format in Exporting Table to XLSX in SAC, from B...
entry.content: This happens because in BW live models the date formatting comes directly from the BW query and SAC exports it to Excel as text, so SAC profile date settings do not apply, and Excel cannot automatically convert dd.mm.yyyy text into a date, so the only solutions are to change the date format in the BW query to an ISO compatible format, expose the date as a proper date characteristic, or convert the text to date inside Excel after export, because SAC cannot change date formats for BW live data during XLSX export.

entry.title: Trading Partner Management in SAP Integration Suite: ANSI X12 EDI Integration
entry.content:
Introduction

Trading Partner Management (TPM) in SAP Integration Suite enables enterprises to manage B2B integrations with partners using standards like ANSI X12. It provides a centralized way to define partner profiles, agreements, connectivity, certificates, and mappings, ensuring smooth exchange of EDI documents with SAP backend systems via IDocs.

 

Step 1: Company Profile

  • Define your own organization in TPM.
  • Include identifiers such as DUNS number, GLN, or custom IDs.
  • This profile represents your company in all agreements.

 

Step 2: Partner Profile

  • Create a profile for each trading partner.
  • Capture identifiers (ISA/GS segments in ANSI X12), contact details, and communication channels.
  • Profiles standardize partner metadata for reuse across agreements.

 

Step 3: Agreements

  • Agreements connect your company profile with a partner profile.
  • Define:
    • Transaction sets (ANSI X12 types).
    • Protocols (AS2, SFTP).
    • Certificates for encryption/signing.
  • Agreements govern how messages are exchanged, validated, and acknowledged.

 

Step 4: Connectivity (AS2 & SFTP)

  • AS2: Configure partner endpoint, certificates, MDN settings, and encryption/signature algorithms.
  • SFTP: Define host, port, authentication (password or SSH key), and inbound/outbound directories.
  • Connectivity ensures secure, reliable transport of EDI files.

 

Step 5: Certificates

  • Upload partner public certificates for AS2 encryption/signing.
  • Maintain your own private/public key pairs.
  • Monitor expiry dates to avoid disruptions.

 

Step 6: Mapping

  • Use Integration Advisor or Cloud Integration to map ANSI X12 transaction sets to SAP IDocs.
  • Example: X12 810 (Invoice) ‚Üí INVOIC02 IDoc.
  • Mapping ensures semantic consistency between external EDI formats and SAP internal structures.

 

Common ANSI X12 Transaction Sets and SAP IDoc Types

| ANSI X12 Transaction Set | SAP IDoc Type | Functionality |
|--------------------------|---------------|---------------|
| 850 ‚Äì Purchase Order | ORDERS05 | Customer purchase orders |
| 810 ‚Äì Invoice | INVOIC02 | Supplier invoice processing |
| 856 ‚Äì Ship Notice/Manifest | DESADV05 | Shipment and delivery notifications |
| 820 ‚Äì Payment Order/Remittance Advice | PEXR2002 / REMADV01 | Payment instructions and remittance advice |
| 940 ‚Äì Warehouse Shipping Order | SHPMNT05 | Warehouse shipment details |
| 945 ‚Äì Warehouse Shipping Advice | SHPMNT05 | Confirmation of goods shipped |
| 997 ‚Äì Functional Acknowledgment | CONTRL | Acknowledgment of EDI messages |
| 844 ‚Äì Product Transfer Account Adjustment | GSVERF01 | Adjustments in product accounts |
| 832 ‚Äì Price/Sales Catalog | PRICAT01 | Exchange of product price catalogs |
| 830 ‚Äì Planning Schedule with Release Capability | DELFOR02 | Forecast of deliveries |
| 846 ‚Äì Inventory Inquiry/Advice | INVRPT01 | Inventory reporting |

 

Additional Considerations

  • Message Implementation Guidelines (MIGs): Define partner-specific rules for each transaction set.
  • Monitoring: Use TPM dashboards to track message flows, acknowledgments, and errors.
  • Migration: Existing SAP PI/PO EDI scenarios can be migrated to TPM using Integration Advisor.
  • Compliance: Ensure mappings align with SAP Note 104606 for ANSI X12 compatibility.

 

Conclusion

By configuring company profiles, partner profiles, agreements, connectivity, certificates, and mappings, enterprises can seamlessly integrate ANSI X12 EDI flows with SAP IDocs in Integration Suite. TPM reduces onboarding complexity, enforces compliance, and accelerates B2B integration projects.

entry.title: Re: Add Custom BO field to standard report
entry.content:
Dear @KhaingZinTun,

In Public Cloud you generally cannot inject a field that lives only in a Custom Business Object (CBO) into an SAP-delivered standard report standard embedded analytics content. Standard reports are built on SAP-delivered analytical queries / CDS data sources and the supported extensibility is clean-core you can extend the report‚Äôs underlying released data source with custom fields / data source extensions but you don‚Äôt modify SAP standard content to pull in arbitrary custom BO tables

Option A: Best if the field semantically belongs to a standard object. Create a Custom Field on the standard business context

If your CBO field is really an attribute of something standard (Sales Order, Journal Entry, Purchase Order, etc.) the most supported path is:

  1. Create a Custom Fields app in the relevant business context
  2. Enable field usage for Reports / analytics so it becomes available in reporting scenarios

This often makes the field usable in reporting and keeps you upgrade-safe

Option B: Best if the data must stay in the CBO. Build your own report using Custom CDS View + Custom Analytical Queries

Create a custom reporting artifact that combines standard + custom data, instead of altering the standard report:

  1. Create a Custom CDS View based on a released SAP VDM view and where keys allow merge/join it with the CBO-generated table/view

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/b0000072fe994d7b9d5e015adf066059.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/8573b810511948c8a99c0672abc159aa.html

  1. Create a Custom Analytical Queries app on top of that CDS view you can copy an existing query and adapt it and you can add/remove custom fields in the query design
  2. Publish it as a tile/KPI/report for end users

More details below:

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F1572')/S35

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/33f3a229ecfe438ca6b2053c48b4e1bb.html

This is the standard clean-core way to report on SAP + custom table/BO together

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Mirror, Mirror - Programming a Magic Mirror in Snap!
entry.content:
This article contains videos, PDF materials, and extension ideas for the Magic Mirror project, where photos or live webcam images can be distorted, coloured, or swirled using Snap!‚Äôs built-in graphic effects.

The project is well suited for programming beginners, since it needs very few blocks. With only a couple of programming concepts required, this project can be used from elementary school onward, but from personal experience we know that it also appeals to older learners üòâ.

 

Part 1: Applying Graphic Effects Interactively to a Photo

The basic idea of this first part of the project is to use the set _ effect to _ block to interactively modify a sprite‚Äôs costume. You can either take a photo with the webcam or import an image from your computer into Snap!.

  • Taking a photo with the webcam:
    In Snap! you can access the webcam e.g. from the Costumes tab. Clicking the camera icon opens a window displaying the webcam feed. To capture a webcam costume, click Save. Clicking the Cancel button closes the webcam window.
    If you are using the webcam for the first time from Snap!, you must enable access. Depending on your browser, a pop-up will appear asking you to allow webcam access. If access is denied, the webcam button will be greyed out. In that case, simply reload the page then the browser asks for permission again.
    Click the Costumes tab and then the webcam icon to open the camera (left). The first time, you must grant access (middle ‚Äî screenshot from Google Chrome; the pop-up may vary by browser). Then, by clicking Save, you can capture a photo costume (right). Cancel closes the camera window.

 

  • Importing an image from your computer:
    If no webcam is available or you want to use other images, you can simply import pictures from your computer. Open the file menu and choose Import‚Ä¶. A file browser window will appear that lets you navigate to the desired image.

 

Resources for the first part of the project:

  • This video guides you step by step through the programming process:
    https://youtu.be/ZyGF0VYqm3k 
  • In this activity card, you find a detailed explanation:
    https://dam.sap.com/mac/u/a/tBkLEtj?rc=10&doi=SAP1267262 
  • This starter project only contains the blocks required for the first and second part of the projects. Starter projects are great when working with younger learners because they reduce cognitive load. However, they also limit the creative options: 
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=Magic%20Mirror%20Starter 
  • This solution project contains the script for the first part of the project. Fisheye and color were chosen as graphic effects to manipulate the photo. The project is started with the green flag, pressing the space key resets the graphic effects. 
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=Magic%20Mirror%20Solution%20-%20Part1 

 

Note for tablet users:

If tablets are used for building or demonstrating the project, one additional step is required. 

On a computer, the mouse x and mouse y positions, which are used to control the effects, can always be accessed. On tablets, this is only possible when an actual touch event happens, meaning a finger or pencil must touch the screen. This however also always counts as a click.

If this click is performed on the photo, the sprite is lifted off the stage and dragged along as the finger moves. You can prevent this by removing the checkmark next to the draggable setting. This ensures that the sprite can only be moved programmatically and no longer by clicking it.

If the draggable box is checked, the sprite can be moved with a mouse click or touch. If the box is unchecked, the sprite can only be moved by the program itself.

 

Part 2: Building a Magic Mirror with Live Video

In the second part of the project, the webcam feed is continuously projected onto a costume. This creates the impression of a live video feed on the mirror sprite. The live image can then be modified again using the graphic effects.

Resources for the second part of the project:

  • This video contains a step by step guide to programming the second part:
    https://youtu.be/42Y95y4RzBs 
  • In this activity card you can find a detailed explanation on how to build the second part of the project:
    https://dam.sap.com/mac/u/a/bgqjCaa?rc=10&doi=SAP1267261 
  • You can use this solution project to check what you've done:
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=Magic%20Mirror%20Solution%20-%20Part2 

 

Extend the project:

In addition to the built-in graphic effects used in part one and two, you can extend the project with further ideas. The blocks for this are not included in the starter project. Here‚Äôs how you can show or hide blocks:

To hide blocks, right-click on the palette and select "hide blocks‚Ä¶". A dialog window with all the available blocks will open.
In this window, you can select individual blocks to hide by clicking the checkbox next to them or you can right-click inside the dialog box and choose the ‚Äúunused‚Äù option. This is especially useful if you only need the blocks relevant to a specific project: simply build your desired result, then hide all unused blocks. 
After clicking OK, the palette will contain only the blocks you did not choose to hide.

If you want to show hidden blocks again, open the ‚Äúhide blocks‚Ä¶‚Äù dialog once more and remove the checkmark next to the blocks you want to display. If you want to show all blocks, right-click in the dialog window, choose ‚Äúnone‚Äù, and then click OK.
All blocks will then be shown in the palette again. 

 

Distorting the image:

Using the stretch block, you can distort a sprite‚Äôs costume. The stretch block has three inputs: the costume to be stretched, and the stretch or squash values for the x- and y-directions. If both directions are set to 100%, nothing changes, the costume keeps its current proportions. If the x-direction is set to values greater than 100% (e.g., 200, see below), the costume becomes wider. Values below 100% make it narrower.
Values below 100% in the y-direction flatten the costume (e.g., 80, see below), and values above 100% make it taller.

Left: the original ‚ÄúEgg‚Äù costume. Right: the ‚ÄúEgg‚Äù costume stretched to 200% in the x-direction (therefore wider) and squashed to 80% in the y-direction (therefore flatter).

To distort the webcam image for the Magic Mirror, you have to take one additional step. If, instead of stretching the Egg-costume, you directly stretch the video snap costume, the costume will become wider and flatter each time the snapshot is applied. This happens because the object‚Äôs dimensions are stretched to x: 200% and y: 80% every time a new snapshot is put on as a costume - in other words, with each new snapshot the object becomes twice as wide and 0.8 times as tall as before.

The costume is stretched every time the webcam snapshot is applied if it is not reset to its original dimensions beforehand.

Therefore, before switching to the video snap costume, you should always switch back to the original ‚ÄúEgg‚Äù costume. This ensures that the stretch and squash remain consistently at x: 200% and y: 80% of the original size.

Before the video snap is applied and stretched to x: 200% and y: 80%, the sprite switches back to the original ‚ÄúEgg‚Äù costume.

 

Mirroring and duplicating the image:

You can also use the stretch block to mirror a costume in different directions by using negative values for the x- and y-stretch inputs. For example, if the x-direction is set to ‚Äì100%, the costume is mirrored horizontally. If the y-direction is set to ‚Äì100%, it is mirrored vertically.

left: video snap on myself, middle: video snap on myself - mirrored horizontally by stretching to -100% in x-direction, right: video snap on self mirrored vertically by stretching to -100% in y-direction

Mirroring alone isn‚Äôt particularly exciting. It becomes fun when you display mirrored and non-mirrored versions of the image on top of each other.

Create two sprites and move them to the same position. 
The bottom sprite simply keeps the video snap as its costume at all times. The top sprite should also continuously display the webcam image as its costume, but horizontally or vertically mirrored.
Then you can use the ghost (transparency) effect to make the top sprite semi-transparent. Now both versions, the mirrored and the original, are visible at the same time.

Two sprites are displayed on top of each other. Both are continuously setting their costume to video snap of myself. For the top sprite, the costume is stretched to ‚Äì100% in the x-direction, meaning it is horizontally mirrored. In addition, the ghost effect of the top sprite is set to 50, allowing both versions, the original and the horizontally mirrored costume, to be visible at the same time.

You can easily display up to four differently mirrored sprites on top of each other; you just need to adjust the transparency effect for each one accordingly.

 

Rotating the image:

The magic mirror can also rotate. The webcam image is displayed in whatever direction the sprite is currently facing. If the sprite is pointing in direction 90, the image appears ‚Äúupright‚Äù meaning the neck is at the bottom. If you set the direction to 45 degrees, the entire sprite and therefore the video snap is rotated by 45 degrees. The neck now points downwards to the right.

To change the direction continuously, you can use a script that slowly rotates the sprite forever.

left: video snap when the sprite is facing in direction 90. middle: video snap when the sprite is pointing towards 45 degrees. right: script that continuously rotates the sprite by 0.2 degrees.

 

Try out the extensions:

left: distorted mirror image created with the stretch block. middle: two sprites placed on top of each other ‚Äî the top one is semi-transparent (ghost effect 50) and mirrored using the stretch block (x: ‚Äì100, y: 100). right: the sprite turns slowly by 0.2 degrees, therefore the mirror image is facing in different directions.

Test the three extensions in the following solution project:
https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=Magic%20Mirror%20Extension 

Press the green flag to start all mirrors. Then press the number key of each mirror to show or hide the corresponding extension.

Key 1 for the distortion mirror
Key 2 for the ‚Äúmirrored‚Äù mirror
Key 3 for the rotating mirror

 

Excursion: Displaying the webcam on other sprites - tips, tricks, and further ideas

The video snap on myself block returns an image that shows the part of the webcam feed that is located behind the sprite executing the block (i.e., "myself"). The image takes the shape of the sprite‚Äôs current costume, regardless of whether the costume was drawn by hand, chosen from the costume library, or imported from your computer.
This also works when the video transparency is set to 100, meaning the webcam feed displayed on the stage is transparent.

The webcam‚Äôs video snap appears on the costume of Alonzo - worn by the sprite running the function.

Sometimes the costume is too small to show the part of the webcam image you want to display on it. In this case, only part of the webcam feed (just one eye instead of the whole face) fits onto the Alonzo costume. Increasing the sprite‚Äôs size, for example, from size 100 to size 250, does not change the portion of the webcam that appears on the sprite. Just like the sprite, the webcam image displayed on it is enlarged, but the cropped segment of the webcam stays the same.

left: the sprite at size 100 with a video snap costume. right: the same sprite at size 250. Everything is scaled up, but the webcam crop stays the same.

If you want to increase the visible area of the webcam feed, you must change the size of the costume, not the sprite itself. You can use the script shown in the following figure. The script that displays the webcam on the sprite can stay as it is. 

top: the sprite at size 100 with its corresponding costume. to the right: the result of the video snap on myself block for this sprite. bottom: the same sprite with an enlarged costume. The script on the left first sets the sprite‚Äôs size to 280. Then it stamps the sprite onto the stage. After that, the sprite‚Äôs size is reset to 100. Subsequently, the stamped marks (pen trails) can be used as a costume. The sprite now has size 100 but with a significantly enlarged costume. This also changes the portion of the webcam image that appears on the costume.top: the sprite at size 100 with its corresponding costume. to the right: the result of the video snap on myself block for this sprite. bottom: the same sprite with an enlarged costume. The script on the left first sets the sprite‚Äôs size to 280. Then it stamps the sprite onto the stage. After that, the sprite‚Äôs size is reset to 100. Subsequently, the stamped marks (pen trails) can be used as a costume. The sprite now has size 100 but with a significantly enlarged costume. This also changes the portion of the webcam image that appears on the costume.

This opens up many additional ideas in the field of media computation with images. For example, how about creating your own graphic effects, such as a negative effect that inverts all colors?
Have you heard of dithering? It‚Äôs a technique among other things used in graphics design that uses only a few colors (in this case, a single shade of green) to create the illusion of greater color depth (here, a ‚Äúgreen-scale‚Äù effect using differently sized green dots).
Or how about generating your own personalized version of Georg Nees‚Äô famous artwork Schotter?

Now it's your turn to get creative or check out further media computation activities  üéº üìú üé•

 

 
These materials are released under a CC-BY-SA 4.0 license by the Snap! team at SAP.

 

‚ÄÉ

entry.title: Re: Securing Enterprise AI on SAP BTP: Zero Trust Authentication with SAP AI Core
entry.content:
Very nice blog!

Could you comment here about the deprecation of SAML on BTP, and whether or not it is preferable to use OIDC-based integration directly instead of SAML?

It is possible to use your corporate IdP in proxy mode from IAS (XSUAA OIDC ‚Üí IAS SAML ‚Üí Corp. IdP), rather than using SAML directly (XSUAA SAML ‚Üí Corp. IdP). While this may seem more complex, it can be simpler, because the trust connection from XSUAA to IAS is very simple to configure using the "Establish Trust" button. Also, the IAS‚ÜíCorp. IdP only needs to be configured once (not once per subaccount). Also, some AI-use cases require XSUAA to use OIDC, not SAML (e.g. Joule for Business in SuccessFactors, S/4, IBP, etc.).

What do you think about continuing to use SAML for new configurations?
